question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
A 40-foot by 10-foot rectangular garden is enclosed by a fence. To make the garden larger, while using the same amount of fencing, its shape is changed to a square. How many square feet larger than the old garden is the new garden?
inference:
The perimeter of the rectangular garden is $2(40+10)=100$ feet.

The perimeter of the square garden is also $100$ feet.

The side length of the square garden is $100/4=25$ feet.

The area of the square garden is $25^2=625$ square feet.

The area of the rectangular garden is $40\times10=400$ square feet.

The area of the new garden is $625-400=225$ square feet larger than the area of the old garden.

Final Answer: $\boxed{225}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: The original garden has an area of $40\cdot 10=400\text{ ft}^2$. Its perimeter is $40+10+40+10=100\text{ ft}$, so a square fence using the same amount of fencing has sides of length $25\text{ ft}$ and an area of $25\cdot 25 = 625\text{ ft}^2$. The increase in area is thus $625 - 400 = \boxed{225}$ square feet.
